We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
rules.title: That

rules.description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
rules.title: That

rules.description:
Correct: Please tell me why you missed the meeting. Incorrect: Please tell me where you missed the meeting.
Why is used to talk about something happening (missed the meeting) for a certain reason.
rules.title: Why

rules.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.
rules.title: Who

rules.description:
Correct: Have you met the girl who started in grade 7 last week? Incorrect: Have you met the girl that started in grade 7 last week?
We use who to give more details about a person (the girl). Who is used for someone (the girl) who does an action (started in grade 7) instead of receiving an action.
rules.title: Practice: Whose, Whom, Who

rules.description:
Correct: My friend Steve, whose job is fun, loves going to work. Incorrect: My friend Steve, who job is fun, loves going to work.
We use whose to give more details about something the subject (Steve) owns (job).
rules.title: Whose

rules.description:
Correct: My father, whom I respect, is a self-made man. Incorrect: My father, who I respect, is a self-made man.
We use whom to give more details about someone (My father) who receives an action (I respect) instead of doing an action. The example above says that someone (I) respects her father, which means that ""father"" receives the action, ""respect"".
rules.title: Whom

rules.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.
rules.title: Which

rules.description:
That: The new classrooms that had their walls painted look great. Which: The new classrooms, which had their walls painted, look great.
We use which to give more details about something (new classrooms), but the details don't change the meaning of the sentence. In the first example, using ""that"" means only the painted classrooms look great. In the second example, using which means that the new classrooms look great, and they also happen to be painted. We usually place commas before which.
rules.title: Practice: Which, That

rules.description:
Incorrect: Did you get the email who I sent this morning? Correct: Did you get the email that I sent this morning?
We use that to give more details about an object (the email). Unlike ""which"", we use that when the details are are important to the meaning of the sentence (that I sent this morning). We usually don't place commas before that.
rules.title: That

Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).

Where is used to talk about something happening (serve drinks) in, on, or at a certain place (living room).

rules.description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like ""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" to the end of the verb (is thinking).
rules.title: Present Progressive

rules.description:
Simple Present: Jesse thinks about seagulls. Present Progressive: Jesse is thinking about seagulls right now.
Present progressive tense describes an ongoing action that is happening right now (Jesse is thinking right now). This tense is made by putting words like â€œam,â€ â€œisâ€, and â€œareâ€ before the verb, and adding â€œingâ€ to the end of the verb (is thinking).
rules.title: Practice: Progressive Tense

rules.description:
Simple Past: James cleaned the mess he made when his mom walked in the room. Past Progressive: James was cleaning the mess he made when his mom walked in the room.
Past progressive tense describes something which was happening (was cleaning) when something else occurred (mom walked in). This tense is made by putting words like""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" at the end of the verb (was cleaning).
rules.title: Past Progressive

rules.description:
Simple Future: Alice will watch TV when her mother comes home. Future Progressive: Alice will be watching TV when her mother comes home.
Future progressive tense describes an ongoing action (watching tv) that will take place in the future (when her mother comes home). This tense is made by putting words like ""am"", ""is"", and ""are"" before the verb, and adding ""ing"" to the end of the verb (will be watching).
rules.title: Future Progressive

rules.description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).
rules.title: Comparative Adjectives

rules.description: Correct: James is taller than Steve. Incorrect: Jame is more tall than Steve. Comparative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is ""more"" or ""less"" than another thing (Steve). Regular comparative adjectives are formed by adding ""er"" to the end of a word (**taller**).
rules.title: Practice: Comparative and Superlative Adjectives

rules.description: Correct: James is the tallest guy in school. Incorrect: James is the most tall guy in school. Superlative adjectives tell us how one thing (James) is the ""most"" or ""least"". Regular superlative adjectives are formed by adding ""est"" to the end of a word (**tallest**).
rules.title: Superlative Adjectives

rules.description: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).
rules.title: Adjectives Ending in ""y""

rules.description: Correct: Papayas are considered to be healthier than bananas. Incorrect: Papayas are considered to be healthyer than bananas. To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) comparative, we change the ""y"" to an ""ier"" to the end of the word (**healthier**).
rules.title: Practice: Comparative and Superlative Adjectives Ending in ""y""

rules.description: Correct: Are papayas the healthiest fruit of all? Incorrect: Are papayas the healthyest fruitof all? To make an adjective ending in ""y"" (healthy) superlative, we change the ""y"" to an ""iest"" to the end of the word (**healthiest**).
rules.title: Adjectives ending in ""y"" (Superlative)

rules.description: ""Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for """"good"""" is better. The superlative adjective for """"good"""" is best.""
rules.title: Better & Best

rules.description: Correct: Who here is the best at playing chess? Incorrect: Who here is the goodest at playing chess? The comparative adjective for ""good"" is better. The superlative adjective for ""good"" is best.
rules.title: Practice: Better & Best, Worse & Worst

rules.description: Correct: It is worse to have never tried than to fail. Incorrect: It is badder to have never tried than to fail. The comparative adjective for ""bad"" is worse. The superlative adjective for ""bad"" is worst.
rules.title: Worse & Worst

rules.description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
rules.title: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

rules.description: Correct: My favorite book is called A Return to the Beginnings of Time and Space. Incorrect: My favorite book is called A return to the beginnings of time and space. When we write out titles, we always capitalize the first word in the title along with proper nouns and longer words. Smaller words like articles (the), conjunctions (but), and prepositions (to) remain in the lower case.
rules.title: Practice: Capitalize Appropriate Words in Titles

rules.description:
Reflexive: I hit myself with a ball playing soccer yesterday. Non-Reflexive: I was hit with a ball while playing soccer yesterday.
If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Myself

rules.description:
Reflexive: I hit myself with a ball playing soccer yesterday. Non-Reflexive: I was hit with a ball while playing soccer yesterday.
If a subject (I) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (myself). In the second example, the subject (I) does not do something to itself, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Practice: Myself, Yourself

rules.description:
Reflexive: Why don't you lift yourself out of the hole? Non-Reflexive: Why don't you lift Alex out of the hole?
If a subject (you) does something to its itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourself). Sentences where the subject (you) does not do something to itself (Alex) do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Yourself

rules.description:
Reflexive: I see that you all really applied yourselves for this assignment. Non-Reflexive: I see that you worked really hard for this assignment.
When we address multiple people (you all) doing something to themselves, we use a reflexive pronoun (yourselves).
rules.title: Yourselves

rules.description:
Reflexive: Steven sees himself becoming team captain one day. Non-Reflexive: I see Steven becoming team captain one day.
If a male subject (Steven) does something to himself, we use a reflexive pronoun (himself). In the second example, the subject (I) is seeing someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Himself

rules.description:
Reflexive: Steven sees himself becoming team captain one day. Non-Reflexive: I see Steven becoming team captain one day.
If a male subject (Steven) does something to himself, we use a reflexive pronoun (himself). In the second example, the subject (I) is seeing someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Practice: Themselves, Ourselves, Itself, Herself.

rules.description:
Reflexive: Jasmine heard herself singing through the speakers. Non-Reflexive: He heard Jasmine singing through the speakers.
If a female subject (Jasmine) does something to herself, we use a reflexive pronoun (herself). In the second example, the subject (He) is listening to someone else, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Herself

rules.description:
Reflexive: My computer can shut itself off. Non-Reflexive: I can shut down my computer.
If an object (computer) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (itself). In the second example, the subject of the sentence (I) is shutting the computer down, and not shutting himself down, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Itself

rules.description:
Reflexive: We worked ourselves to the point of exhaustion. Non-Reflexive: Our company works almost 80 hours a week.
If the subject (We) does something to itself, we use a reflexive pronoun (ourselves). In the second example, the company is making us work instead of us working ourselves, so we do not use a reflexive pronoun.
rules.title: Ourselves

rules.description:
Is: John is behind the curtain. Are: The men are next to the bar. Am: I am under a bridge.
A nominal prepositional phrase is used to say where something is. Nominal prepositional phrases (behind the curtain, next to the bar, under a bridge) are placed after the verb to be (is, are, am).
rules.title: At (Time)

rules.description:
Correct: I will meet my friend at noon. Incorrect: I will meet my friend on noon.
We use the preposition at for specific times, like 1:30 PM or 7:00 AM.
rules.title: Practice: At, In, On (Time)

rules.description:
Correct: I will meet my cousin in the fall. Incorrect: I will meet my cousin at the fall.
We use in for months, seasons, and times of day, like October, winter or morning.
rules.title: In (Time)

rules.description:
Correct: I will meet with my counselor on Monday. Incorrect: I will meet with my counselor in Monday.
We use on for days of the week and certain dates, like Monday or October 30th.
rules.title: On (Time)

rules.description:
Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.
rules.title: At (Place)

rules.description:
Correct: Lots of people wait at the bus stop. Incorrect: Lots of people wait in the bus stop.
We use at to talk about exact locations, like at the bus stop, or at home.
rules.title: Practice: At, In, On (Place)

rules.description:
Correct: I had a great time in London. Incorrect: I had a great time at London.
We use in when we are inside or within a place, like in France, or in a car.
rules.title: In (Place)

rules.description:
Correct: My grandparents keep a picture of me on their mantle. Incorrect: My grandparents keep a picture of me at their mantle.
We use on for anything on a surface, like walls and tables.
rules.title: On (Place)

rules.description:
Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).
rules.title: A

rules.description:
Incorrect: I climbed an tree. Correct: I climbed a tree.
Articles (a) are used before nouns (tree). The article an is used before nouns that start with vowel sounds (a, e, i, o, u).
rules.title: An

rules.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.
rules.title: Practice: This & That

rules.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.
rules.title: This & That

rules.description:
Close by: This picture here is crooked. Further away: That picture over there is crooked.
You use this and that when you are talking a single thing (a picture). You use this for things near you and that for things further away.
rules.title: This & That

rules.description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).
rules.title: Practice: A, An, The

rules.description:
Indefinite Article: There is lots of pizza. I ate a slice. Definite Article: There was a loaded slice of bacon pizza. I ate the slice.
You use a definite article (the) to specify something (the slice of bacon pizza). You use an indefinite article (a, an) when you have not specified something (a slice).
rules.title: The

rules.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.
rules.title: These & Those

rules.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.

rules.description:
Close by: These shoes are dirty. Further away: Those dogs are cute.
You use these and those when you are talking about more than one thing. You use these for things near you and those for things further away.
rules.title: Practice: These & Those

rules.description:
Active Voice: The student use Quill.
Passive Voice: Quill is used by the students.
A verb's voice tells whether a subject receives or performs an action. If the subject receives the action, it is passive, and if the subject performs the action, it is active.
The passive voice is usually written with a form of ""to be"" and then the past participle of a verb.
rules.title: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-1
Practice: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences

rules.description:
Active Voice: The student use Quill.
Passive Voice: Quill is used by the students.
A verb's voice tells whether a subject receives or performs an action. If the subject receives the action, it is passive, and if the subject performs the action, it is active.
The passive voice is usually written with a form of ""to be"" and then the past participle of a verb.
rules.title: Change into Proper Passive or Active Sentences-2

rules.description:
Active Voice: Tom (subject) shipped (verb) the package.
Passive Voice: The passage (subject) was shipped (verb) by Tom.
To change a sentence from the active voice to the passive voice, you must change the subject so that instead of doing the verb, the verb is being done to it.
rules.title: Change Sentences from Active to Passive-1
Practice: Change Sentences from Active to Passive
Practice: Change Sentences from Passive to Active

rules.description:
Passive Voice: The sausage (subject) was eaten (verb) by Ryan.
Active Voice: Ryan (subject) ate (verb) the sausage.
To change a sentence from the passive voice to the active voice, you must change the subject so that instead of the verb being done to it, the subject does the verb.
rules.title: Change Sentences from Passive to Active-1

rules.description:
Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).
rules.title: Ends with ""fe""

rules.description:
Correct: Some people say cats have nine lives. Incorrect: Some people say cats have nine lifes.
Nouns that end in ""fe"" (life) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""fe"" (life) to ""ves"" (lives).
rules.title: rregular Plural Nouns Practice: Ending With ""F,"" ""Fe,"" and ""O.""

rules.description:
Correct: Two halves always make a whole. Incorrect: Two halfs always make a whole.
Nouns that end in ""f"" (half) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we change the ""f"" (half) to ""ves"" (halves).
rules.title: Ends with ""f""

rules.description:
Correct: Do you know how many potatoes can fit in this sack? Incorrect: Do you know how many potatos can fit in this sack?
Nouns that end in ""o"" (potato) have an irregular plural form. To make them plural, we add an ""es"" to the end of the word (potatoes).
rules.title: Ends with ""o""

rules.description:
Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).
rules.title: Man vs. Men

rules.description:
Correct: Are you mice, or are you men? Incorrect: Are you mice, or are you mans?
The word ""man"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (man) to an ""e"" (men).
rules.title: Practice: Man, Woman

rules.description:
Correct: The group of women won the tug of war. Incorrect: The group of woman won the tug of war.
The word ""woman"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""a"" (woman) to an ""e"" (women).
rules.title: Man/Men, Woman/Women-2

""Correct: Can you juggle the ball with both feet? Incorrect: Can you juggle the ball with both foots?
The word """"foot"""" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double """"o"""" (foot) into a double """"e"""" (feet).

The word ""foot"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (foot) into a double ""e"" (feet).
rules.title: Practice: Feet, Teeth

The word ""tooth"" has an irregular plural form, similar to the word ""foot"". To make it plural, we change the double ""o"" (tooth) into a double ""e"" (teeth).
rules.title: Tooth vs. Teeth

rules.description:
Correct: Where are the children playing right now? Incorrect: Where are the childs playing right now?
The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).
rules.title: Child vs. Children

rules.description:

The word ""child"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we add ""ren"" to the end (children).
rules.title: Practice: Children, People

rules.description:
Correct: I think we can fit at least three people in each room. Incorrect: I think we can fit at least three persons in each room.
The word ""person"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""rson"" (person) to ""ople"" (people).
rules.title: Person vs. People

rules.description:
Correct: I think there are some mice living in the walls. Incorrect: I think there are some mouses living in the walls.
The word ""mouse"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""ouse"" (mouse) to ""ice"" (mice).
rules.title: Mouse vs. Mice

rules.description:
Correct: I think there are some mice living in the walls. Incorrect: I think there are some mouses living in the walls.
The word ""mouse"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""ouse"" (mouse) to ""ice"" (mice).
rules.title: Practice: Mice, Goose, Deer

rules.description:
Correct: I saw a bunch of geese flying in the sky. Incorrect: I saw a bunch of gooses flying in the sky.
The word ""goose"" has an irregular plural form. To make it plural, we change the ""oose"" (mouse) to ""eece"" (goose).
rules.title: Mouse/Mice, Geese/Goose, Deer/Deer-2

rules.description:
""Singular: I saw a deer crossing the road earlier. Plural: I saw ten deer crossing the road earlier.
The word """"deer"""" does not change when it becomes plural.
""
rules.title: Deer

rules.description:
Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.
rules.title: Singular And Plural Nouns

rules.description:
Subject is I: I run a half-mile everyday. Subject is She: She runs a half-mile everyday.
Subjects (I, she) and verbs (run, runs) have to agree with each other. If the subject of a sentence is ""I"", ""you"" or ""they"", we don't change the verb. If the subject is ""he"", ""she"", or ""it"", we add an ""s"" to the end of the verb.
rules.title: Practice: Singular And Plural Nouns

rules.description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.
rules.title: Common Nouns

rules.description:
Examples: man, woman, city, country, baseball team.
Common nouns are ordinary words for people, places, and things, such as man, or country. Common nouns are not capitalized.
rules.title: Practice: Common and Proper Nouns

rules.description:
Examples: John, Sarah, London, Japan, and Yankees
Proper nouns are names for people, places, and things, such as John, or Japan. All proper nouns are capitalized.
rules.title: Proper Nouns

rules.description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
rules.title: Possessive Nouns

rules.description: Example: My father's stamp collection is huge. Example: The ship's sails were filled with a gust of wind. Possessive nouns are used to show ownership. To make most common or proper nouns possessive, we add an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
rules.title: Practice: Possessive Nouns

rules.description:
Correct: The red team scored the winning goal in the game. Incorrect: The red panel scored the winning goal in the game.
Collective nouns are words like team, panel, bunch, pack, etc. They usually are singular and describe a group of things (group of people).
Team is a collective noun generally used to describe a group working towards a common cause, or in competition with another group. For example, a sports team, oxen team, or
rules.title: Use Collective Nouns-1

rules.description:
Correct: Thepanel of jurors found him innocent. Incorrect: Thebunch of jurors found him innocent.
Panel is a collective noun generally used to describe a group of figures with authority that are discussing something. For example, judges, juries, advisors, aids, etc...
rules.title: Use Collective Nouns-2

rules.description:
Correct: There are 12 diapers in a pack. Incorrect: There are 12 diapers in a pack.
Pack is a collective noun that can have many different meanings. It can be a group of things packaged together, for example, soda, gum, or candy. It can also refer to groups of animals that live together, especially wolves.
rules.title: Use Collective Nouns-3

rules.description:
Correct: There is a huge group of people at the front gate. Incorrect: There is a huge bunch of people at the front gate.
Group is a collective noun that usually refers to a number of people or objects that are nearby or considered together as one unit. For example, a group of students, a group of packages, a group of fruits, etc...
rules.title: Use Collective Nouns-4

rules.description:
Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.
rules.title: Past Tense

rules.description:
Past: I walked to school. Present: I walk to school.
When we want to talk about things that happened earlier, we usually add ""ed"" to the end of regular verbs to make them past tense.
rules.title: Practice: Past Tense Verbs

rules.description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).
rules.title: Future Tense

rules.description:
Future: I will walk to school. Present: I walk to school.
We use the future tense to describe things that we think will happen. To make the future tense ( will walk ), we add the helping verb ""will"" before the verb ( walk ).
rules.title: Practice: Future Tense

rules.description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.
rules.title: And

rules.description:
Not Connected: I like spaghetti. I like hamburgers. Connected: I like spaghetti and I like hamburgers.
And connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, we use and to show that the subject ( I ) likes both spaghetti and hamburgers.
rules.title: Practice: And, Or

rules.description:
Not Connected: Would you like spaghetti? Would you like a hamburger? Connected: Would you like spaghetti, or would you like a hamburger?
Or connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, or is used to show a choice between spaghetti or a hamburger.
rules.title: Or

rules.description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.
rules.title: So

rules.description:
Not Connected: I don't like hamburgers. I will have spaghetti. Connected: I don't like hamburgers, so I will have spaghetti.
So connects two related sentences into one larger one. In the example, so is used because the subject (I) does not like hamburgers, and has spaghetti instead.
rules.title: Practice: So, Because

rules.description:
Not Connected: I like this spaghetti. There is a lot of cheese in it. Connected: I like this spaghetti because there is a lot of cheese in it.
Because connects two sentences into one longer sentence. In the example, because is used to show that the amount of cheese is the reason the spaghetti is liked.
rules.title: Because

rules.description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).
rules.title: Adjectives

rules.description:
Adjective: The park we visited was really beautiful. Adverb: You performed beautifully yesterday.
Adjectives (beautiful) are used to describe nouns (park).
rules.title: Practice: Adjectives and Adverbs

rules.description:
Adjective: My car is really slow. Adverb: I drive slowly when it is raining.
Adverbs are used to describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They usually describe how an action is being done (drive slowly).
rules.title: Adverbs

rules.description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).
rules.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Consonant Ending

rules.description:
Adjective: Careful, that knife is sharp. Adverb: I sharply turned the car around.
If an adjective ends in a consonant (sharp), then we usually add ""ly"" onto the end of the adjective to make it an adverb (sharply).
rules.title: Practice: Adjectives to Adverbs: Consonant Ending and ""y"" Ending

rules.description:
Adjective: I was really happy this morning. Adverb: I will happily go out tonight.
Adjectives ending in ""y"" (happy), become adverbs by changing the ""y"" to an ""i"", and then adding ""ly""(happily).
rules.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""y""

rules.description:
Adjective: I think this task is pretty simple. Adverb: You simply put the ball in the net.
Adjectives ending in ""le"" (simple), become adverbs by changing the ""le"" to ""ly""(simply).
rules.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""le""
Practice: Ajectives to Adverbs in ""le"" and ""e""

rules.description:
Adjective: You are brave enough to face your fears. Adverb: Rita bravely faced her fears.
Adjectives ending in ""e"" (brave), become adverbs by simply adding ""ly"" to the end of the word (bravely).
rules.title: Adjectives to Adverbs: Ending in ""e""

rules.description:
Separate: I can not see in the dark. Contraction: I can't see in the dark.
To make ""can"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write can't.
rules.title: Can't

rules.description:
Separate: I will not sign anything until I've read the contract. Contraction: I won't sign anything until I've read the contract.
To make ""will"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write won't.
rules.title: Won't

rules.description:
Separate: I have been to Mexico before. Contraction: I've been to Mexico before.
To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.
rules.title: I've

rules.description:
Separate: I have been to Mexico before. Contraction: I've been to Mexico before.
To make a contraction with ""I"" and ""have"", we write I've.
rules.title: Practice: I've, That's, It's

rules.description:
Separate: That is a good idea. Contraction: That's a good idea.
To make a contraction with ""that"" and ""is"", we write that's.
rules.title: That's

rules.description:
Separate: It is really great you decided to come. Contraction: It's really great you decided to come.
To make a contraction with ""it"" and ""is"", we write it's.
rules.title: It's

rules.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for ""I am"" is made by writing I'm.
rules.title: Practice: Contractions

rules.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for ""I am"" is made by writing I'm.
rules.title: I'm, You're, Let's

rules.description:
Separate: I am responsible for managing the team. Contraction: I'm responsible for managing the team.
The contraction for """"I am"""" is made by writing I'm.
""
rules.title: You're

rules.description: Correct: Let's play a board game together. Incorrect: Lets play a board game together. Let's means ""let us"" and is used for suggestions. Lets without an apostrophe means ""to allow.""
rules.title: Let's

rules.description:
Separate: I have not contacted Mrs. Robinson. Contraction: I haven't contacted Mrs. Robinson.
To make ""have"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write haven't.
rules.title: Haven't

rules.description:
Separate: I have not contacted Mrs. Robinson. Contraction: I haven't contacted Mrs. Robinson.
To make ""have"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write haven't.
rules.title: Practice: Haven't, Don't

rules.description:
Separate: I do not go to school on Saturday. Contraction: I don't go to school on Saturday.
To make ""do"" and ""not"" a contraction, we write don't.
rules.title: Practice: Contractions

rules.description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.
rules.title: Use Commas in Addresses

rules.description: Correct: My address is 79 Brookfield Lane, Springfield, Massachusetts 01234. Incorrect: My address is 79 brookfield lane Springfield, Massachusetts, 01234. When we write out our addresses, we always put commas after the name of the street (Brookfield Lane,) and after the name of the city (Springfield). Remember to capitalize both the street and state names, because they are proper nouns.
rules.title: Practice: Use Commas in Addresses

rules.description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.
rules.title: Lost

rules.description: Correct: My favorite team has lost only once this season. Incorrect: My favorite team has losed only once this season. The past participle for ""lose"" is lost.
rules.title: Practice: Made, Lost, Gone

rules.description: Correct: We have made many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. Incorrect: We have maked many mistakes before coming to the right conclusion. The past participle for ""make"" is made.
rules.title: Made

rules.description: Correct: Velma has gone to visit her brother in the hospital. Incorrect: Velma has goed to visit her brother in the hospital. The past participle of ""go"" is gone.
rules.title: Gone

rules.description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".
rules.title: Regular Past Participles

rules.description: With a Helping Verb: I have walked to the library before. As an Adjective: Gene had chilled fruit with his lunch. Regular past participles are made by adding ""ed"" to the end of the verbs. We use the past participle with helping verbs like ""have"" or ""had"" (I have walked). Past participles can also be used as adjectives when they come before nouns (chilled fruit), or when they follow the verb ""be"".
rules.title: Practice: Eaten, Been, Regular Past Participles

rules.description: Correct: I have eaten pancakes before. Incorrect: I have eated pancakes before. The past participle for ""eat"" is eaten.
rules.title: Eaten

rules.description: Correct: I have been in a band before. Incorrect: I have beed in a band before. The past participle for ""be"" is been.
rules.title: Been

rules.description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but."" We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).
rules.title: However

rules.description: With However: My friend said the ride was safe. However, I didn't believe him. Without However: My friend said the ride was safe. I did not believe him. We use however at the beginning of a sentence to say ""nevertheless"" or ""but"". We place a comma after however (However, I did not believe him).
rules.title: Practice: However, Still

rules.description: With Still: I don't like roller coasters. Still, I think theme parks are fun. Without Still: I don't like roller coasters. I think theme parks are fun. We use still at the beginning of a sentence to say something is true despite what was said earlier. We place a comma after still (Still, I think theme parks are fun).
rules.title: Still

rules.description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).
rules.title: Meanwhile

rules.description: With Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping. Without Meanwhile: I was cleaning the whole house. My brother was still sleeping. We use meanwhile at the beginning of a sentence to say two events are happening at the same time. We place a comma after meanwhile (Meanwhile, my brother was still sleeping).
rules.title: Practice: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases

rules.description: Correct: In 1492, Columbus crossed the ocean blue. IncorrectIn 1492 Columbus crossed the ocean blue. When a sentence begins with a prepositional phrase (on the docks, at the park, in 1522), we always put a comma the introductory prepositional phrase.
rules.title: Commas after Introductory Prepositional Phrases

rules.description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.
rules.title: Using Periods

rules.description:
Correct: I went to the zoo. I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo.I saw an elephant. Incorrect: I went to the zoo .I saw an elephant.
We put a space after a period.
rules.title: Practice: Spaces with Punctuation

rules.description:
Correct: Victor, Lucas, and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor,Lucas,and Don play basketball. Incorrect: Victor ,Lucas ,and Don play basketball.
We put a space after a comma. We do not put a space before a comma.
rules.title: Using Commas

rules.description:
Correct: 1,500,000 Incorrect: 1, 500, 000
We do not put a space before or after a comma when we are writing numbers.
rules.title: Using Commas with Numbers

rules.description:
Correct: They hiked 1.7 miles. Incorrect: They hiked 1. 7 miles.
We do not put a space before or after a period when we are writing numbers.
rules.title: Using Periods with Numbers

rules.description: Correct: Our librarian always reminds us, ""Speak softly in the library."" Incorrect: Our librarian always reminds us, "" Speak softly in the library."" Whenever we use quotation marks, they always go right next to a word or punctuation (""Speak softly in the library.""). We never put in extra spaces between quotation marks and the words next to them.
rules.title: Using Quotation Marks

rules.description: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That had didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.
rules.title: Verb Tense Shift

rules.description: Correct: That hat doesn't fit me because it is too small. Incorrect: That hat didn't fit me because it is too small. Everything that happens in the present must be written in the present tense (doesn't fit me because it is too small). For things that happen in the past, everything must be written in the past tense. Lastly, everything that happens in the future must be written in the future tense.
rules.title: Verb Tense Shift

rules.description: Correct: If I were you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. Incorrect: If I was you, I wouldn't drive down this road at night. When we wish for something, or wonder if something could happen, we use ""were"" instead of ""was"". If it is something that could or has been true, we use ""was"" instead of were.
rules.title: Verb Mood Shift

rules.description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.""
rules.title: Misplaced Modifiers

rules.description: Correct: The drawing on the refrigerator was done by my son. Incorrect: The drawing was done by my son on the refrigerator. It is best to describe everything about something (drawing on the refrigerator) before mentioning other people or things related to it (done by my son). The first example mentions a drawing that is on the refrigerator, while the second example shows an odd situation where the son was on top of the refrigerator.
rules.title: Practice: Misplaced Modifiers

rules.description:
Intensive: I myself organized the meeting. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the word emphasizes the the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). When the word is used as a reflexive pronoun, it emphasizes what the subject does to itself (organized myself).
rules.title: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns

rules.description:
Intensive: I organized the meeting myself. Reflexive: I organized myself before going to the meeting.
Intensive Pronouns (myself) use the same words as reflexive pronouns (myself). However, when using intensive pronouns, the subject (I) emphasizes that it does something (organized the meeting). It did not do something to itself (organized myself).
rules.title: Practice: Intensive Pronouns vs. Reflexive Pronouns

rules.description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.
rules.title: Subjective Pronouns

rules.description:
Correct: I will conduct the meeting. Incorrect: Me will conduct the meeting. Also Incorrect: Mine will conduct the meeting.
Subject pronouns (I) are words like ""I,"" ""you,"" ""he,"" ""she,"" ""it,"" ""we,"" ""you,"" and ""they."" They are usually near the front of the sentence and go before the verb.
rules.title: Practice: Subjective, Objective, and Possessive Pronouns

rules.description:
Correct: Will you please call her when you finish the poster? Incorrect: Will you please call she when you finish the poster? Also Incorrect: Will you please call hers when you finish the poster?
Object pronouns (her) are words like ""me"", ""you"", ""him"", ""her"", ""it"", ""us"", and ""them"". Object pronouns go after the verb (call).
rules.title: Object Pronouns

rules.description:
Correct: Our project is more difficult than theirs. Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than they. Also Incorrect: Our project is more difficult than them.
Possessive pronouns (theirs) are words like ""mine"", ""yours"", ""his"", ""hers"", ""its"", ""ours"", and ""theirs"". They refer to something the subject owns (project).
rules.title: Possessive Pronouns

rules.description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to confirm what we just asked, or suggest an answer. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we). If the first part is negative, then the tag question is positive.
rules.title: Tag Questions

rules.description: Positive: We are going to make it, aren't we? Negative: You aren't on my team, are you? Tag questions are little questions that we place at the end of sentences when we want to agree, disagree, or confirm what someone just said. If the first part of the sentence is positive (we are going to make it) then the tag question is negative (aren't we).
rules.title: Practice: Commas for ""Yes"" and ""No,"" Tag Questions, and Addressing People

rules.description: Correct: Yes, my husband is a lawyer. Incorrect: Yes my husband is a lawyer. Correct: No, I don't want to go. Incorrect: No I don't want to go. When we begin a sentence with yes or no, we always put a comma afterwards.
rules.title: Yes & No

rules.description: Correct: Can we go, Paul? Incorrect: Can we go Paul? Correct: Sarah, you should go to practice. Incorrect: Sarah you should go to practice. If we address somebody at the end of a sentence, we place a comma before their name. If we address somebody at the beginning of a sentence we place a comma after their name.
rules.title: Addressing People

rules.description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.
rules.title: Commas in a List

rules.description: Correct: This box has books, magazines, and newspaper articles. Incorrect: This box has books magazines and newspaper articles. We place commas after each item in a list (books, magazines,). We finish a list by placing the word ""and"" before the last item.
rules.title: Practice: Colons and Commas in a List

rules.description: Correct: The box was filled with stuff: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. Incorrect: The box has: two pairs of shoes, some keys, and a cup. We use colons (filled with stuff:) to begin a list. Colons can only be used after complete sentences. Colons are never placed after main verb of the sentence they are added too. After the colon begins the list, we place commas after each item in the list.
rules.title: Colons

rules.description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.
rules.title: First Word of a Sentence

rules.description:
Correct: You should climb Mount Washington. Incorrect: you should climb Mount Washington.
Whenever we begin a new sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (You) of the sentence.
rules.title: Practice: Correct Capitalization

rules.description:
Correct: Do you have a class with Mr. Thompson? Incorrect: Do you have a class with mr. thompson?
We always capitalize the first letter of proper nouns (Mr. Thompson), which are people, places, and things, with names. We also capitalize any titles that might come before the proper noun, such as Mr., Ms., Dr., President, Professor, ect. Don't forget, ""I"" is a proper noun and is always capitalized.
rules.title: Proper Nouns

rules.description:
Correct: We heard a booming voice shout, ""Who are you?"" Incorrect: We heard a booming voice shout, ""who are you?""
When we use quotations in a sentence, we always capitalize the first letter of the first word (Who) of the quote as though it was starting a new sentence.
rules.title: Quotations

rules.description:
Correct: I live on 15 Deepwood Rd in Hartford CT. Incorrect: I live on 15 deepwood rd in hartford ct.
The names of roads, towns, and states in addresses are all proper nouns, so they are capitalized. Don't forget to capitalize all the proper nouns in your address whenever you write it down.
rules.title: Addresses

rules.description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
rules.title: Singular Possessive

rules.description:
Correct: I think that is Jane's notebook. Incorrect: That is Janes notebook.
Possessive nouns are used to show ownership of the noun written after it (Jane's notebook). Singular possessive nouns are usually made by adding an apostrophe and an ""s"" to the end of the word.
rules.title: Practice: Possessive Nouns

rules.description: Correct: The saddles on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Incorrect: The saddle's on each horse were both comfortable and stylish. Plural words that do not own something are written without an apostrophe. Words with an apostrophe placed before an ""s"" are singular possessive words.
rules.title: Plural vs. Singular Possessive

rules.description: Many Boys: Do not touch the boys' gear. One Boy: Do not touch the boy's gear. When multiple people or things own something we place an apostrophe after the ""s"" (boys'). When just one person or thing owns something we put the apostrophe before the ""s"".
rules.title: Plural Possessive

rules.description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).
rules.title: Use Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

rules.description: Correct: A wise man one said, ""Doubt everything, find your own light."" Incorrect: A wise man once said ""Doubt everything, find your own light. We use a pair of quotation marks to show that someone is speaking. Whenever we use quotation marks, we always put a comma before the beginning of the quote (said,).
rules.title: Practice: Commas and Quotation Marks in Dialogue

rules.description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
rules.title: Holidays

rules.description:
Correct: Which holiday is closest to today, Christmas, Hanukkah, Valentine's Day, or Easter? Incorrect: Which holiday is closest to today, christmas, hanukkah, valentines day, or easter?
When we write holiday names, we always capitalize the first letter of all the words (New Year's Eve, Christmas Day, Fourth of July).
rules.title: Practice: Capitalize Holidays, Product Names, and Geographic Names

rules.description:
Correct: My favorite baseball team is the Yankees. Incorrect: My favorite baseball team is the yankees.
We capitalize all product names. Product names include companies (Microsoft), sports teams (Yankees), and brand names (Coca-Cola).
rules.title: Product Names

rules.description:
Correct: I am moving to Los Angeles next month. Incorrect: I am moving to los angeles next month.
We capitalize the names of all geographic places (cities, countries, towns, mountains, etc).
rules.title: Geographic Names

rules.description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).
rules.title: Writing the Date

rules.description:
Correct: August 30th, 1972 Incorrect: 1972, 30th, August
When we write dates, we start with the month (August), then the day (30th), and end with the year (1972). We also put a comma in between the day and the year (August 30th, 1972).
rules.title: Practice: Use Commas for Dates and Lists

rules.description:
Incorrect: I'll have milk and toast and a muffin. Correct: I'll have milk, toast, and a muffin.
When we write lists of three or more, we put a comma after each item in the list. We also put the word ""and"" before the last item of the list.
rules.title: Writing Lists

rules.description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).
rules.title: Capitalization: Dates

rules.description:
Correct: My birthday is on Wednesday, May 4th, 1994. Incorrect: My birthday is on wednesday, may 4th, 1994.
We capitalize the names of specific days and months (Wednesday, May).
rules.title: Practice: Capitalizing Dates and Names of People

rules.description:
Correct: Sarah's birthday is coming soon. Incorrect: sarah's birthday is coming soon.
We capitalize names of people (Sarah, Abraham Lincoln).
rules.title: Capitalization: Names
